items.title: [Question] How to handle lifetime management within a plugin?
items.body:
# Preface
* Have a plugin for SeleniumLibrary
* Plugin will start a thread to handle some things that should happen in the background.

This leads to hanging robot execution at exit because the thread is still running. An issue that i see with this is there aint no clear events when my code should stop the thread execution.

# Possible approaches ? 
* I could add LISTENER, but that feels a bit dirty since the plugin itself is not the main "library" (and thus, it might not even work).
* __del__ of the plugin doesnt seem to get called at end of execution.
* offload starting and stopping of separate process to the person/scripts running the tests.

Essentially the scenario is that i want to attach a proxy running in separate thread to a specific driver instance and kill that specific proxy when the driver is closed. This would be straight forward if webdriver.$BrowserName classes could be overwritten as there there is quit() method when a browser is closed.

Any other ideas ?

items.title: Ability to change Renderer Timeout for Click... Keyword
items.body:
Im looking for a way (a configuration or a simple tweak) to extend the timeout of the renderer when we use the Click... Keywords family.

Background:
I'm using Robotframework + Selenium to automate tasks in Chrome. After 9 steps successfully, the last step (which is similar in terms of instructions to the previous ones) failed because of this error:
TimeoutException: Message: timeout: Timed out receiving message from renderer: 300.000 (Session info: chrome=81.0.4044.138)
At this keyword: Click Element
What it does is that it clicks the element that triggers the file upload and this process is extremely long, about an hour to complete.

What I've done so far is set all the timeout value to a big number, but the renderer timeout is still 300 seconds.
I'm looking for a way to configure this default number, like, the Click Element (or Click Button, etc.) should wait forever if it has to, not throwing a renderer timeout error.

I'm posting an issue here if anyone know a better way to do or somehow change the default value of the renderer timeout (300 seconds I guess?)

items.body:
There was a complaint in the Robot Framework user group that [Open Browser](https://robotframework.org/SeleniumLibrary/SeleniumLibrary.html#Open%20Browser) keyword `service_log_path` is not used correctly with Firefox browser. In the output.xml, this is seen:
```
<msg timestamp="20200330 15:42:29.622" level="TRACE">Arguments: [ 'http://192.168.0.103:8777/' | 'firefox' | 'service_log_path = /path/to/test/GECKODRIVER_LOG' ]</msg>
<msg timestamp="20200330 15:42:29.622" level="INFO">Opening browser 'firefox' to base url 'http://192.168.0.103:8777/'.</msg>
<msg timestamp="20200330 15:42:29.633" level="INFO">Firefox driver log is always forced to to: /path/to/test/geckodriver-2.log</msg>
<msg timestamp="20200330 15:42:29.793" level="DEBUG">POST http://127.0.0.1:56949/session {"capabilities": {"alwaysMatch": {"acceptInsecureCerts": true, "browserName": "firefox", "moz:firefoxOptions": {"pro
```
But the line 
`<msg timestamp="20200330 15:42:29.633" level="INFO">Firefox driver log is always forced to to: /path/to/test/geckodriver-2.log</msg>
` is giving wrong message and it looks like `service_log_path` argument is ignored. Needs investigation.

import sys
from robotremoteserver import RobotRemoteServer
if __name__ == '__main__':     
    RobotRemoteServer(SeleniumLibrary(),*sys.argv[1:])"
in '/SeleniumLibrary/__init__.py'.
After I run the __init__.py,the error message "SeleniumLibrary.errors.NoOpenBrowser: No browser is open." arises.

## Steps to reproduce the issue
1.download 'robotremoteserver.py' to 'site-package/SeleniumLibrary'.
2.add scripts "
import sys

items.title: Choose File keyword incorrectly checks file path when running on a remote machine
items.body:
The issue is that the Choose File keyword, when run on a remote system, checks the file path when it should not.  It then incorrectly errors out because it cannot find the file, even though the file is present.  When run locally, no error occurs and the keyword works as expected.

## Steps to reproduce the issue

The code I am using is as follows:

choose file     ${ef_image_browse_button}    ${normalized_logo_filepath}

where ${normalized_logo_filepath} in my case is /Users/melissa/repos/qa-automation/Resources/Files/liveoak-logo.png

When I run this on my local machine, it passes.  When I run it on a remote machine (in my case, SauceLabs), it fails as follows:
InvalidArgumentException: Message: invalid argument: File not found : /Users/melissa/repos/qa-automation/Resources/Files/liveoak-logo.png

Expected behavior is that it would pass when run locally and remote.  

Based on the Selenium Library documentation, the first issue is that the file path should not even be checked as of version 4.0.  The second issue is that it is incorrectly flagging the file as not found.  

These are the run commands I am using: 
Local run command:
 python3 -m robot --include email_formatting -V local_variables.py -v ENVIRONMENT:develop --listener Library/debug_listener.py Tests

Remote run command:
python3 -m robot -i email_formatting -V local_variables.py -v ENVIRONMENT:develop -v REMOTE_URL:http://\<username\>:\<key\>@ondemand.saucelabs.com:80/wd/hub -v DESIRED_CAPABILITIES:'name:Win10_Chrome 77,platform:Windows 10,browserName:chrome,version:77.0,idleTimeout:500' Tests

The main difference is that for the remote run, remote_url in Open Browser is set to REMOTE_URL.

I tested this with SeleniumLibrary versions 4.1, 4.2, and 3.2.   4.1 and 4.2 both failed, 3.2 passed with the remote url.  

##Stacktrace:

items.title: Wait For Condition Keyword should graciously stomach JavascriptExceptions
items.body:
Hello, please find the time to have a look-see down below  :)

# Prerequisites

- Searched for similar issues in open and closed tickets and cannot find a duplicate.
- Confirmed buggy behavior/issue exists in both versions 3.1.1 and 4.1.0 of SeleniumLibrary.
- I've already read through the User Guide and SeleniumLibrary's documentation without success.
- I am not using the Java Selenium2Library.
- No sensitive information being provided.

# For issues
## Steps to reproduce the issue

Create a simplified example which reproduces the problem. It is good if the example
can be run also by us, but this is not always mandatory.

## Error messages and additional information
##--loglevel trace stacktrace
```<kw name="Wait For Condition" library="SeleniumLibrary">
<doc>
Waits until ``condition`` is true or ``timeout`` expires.
</doc>
<arguments>
<arg>
return document.querySelector('div.acc-Document_HeaderInfoItemRow2 cmp-text-input input').value == '${ACCOUNTS_PAYABLE_INVOICE_NUMBER}';
</arg>
<arg>timeout=18s</arg>
</arguments>
<msg timestamp="20191209 17:24:39.957" level="TRACE">
Arguments: [ "return document.querySelector('div.acc-Document_HeaderInfoItemRow2 cmp-text-input input').value == 'QrLmgWXPIk';" | timeout='18s' ]
</msg>
<msg timestamp="20191209 17:24:39.957" level="DEBUG">
POST http://127.0.0.1:52264/session/c858e0d3adabe28dcb83003ceae0980e/execute/sync {"script": "return document.querySelector('div.acc-Document_HeaderInfoItemRow2 cmp-text-input input').value == 'QrLmgWXPIk';", "args": []}
</msg>
<msg timestamp="20191209 17:24:39.967" level="DEBUG">
http://127.0.0.1:52264 "POST /session/c858e0d3adabe28dcb83003ceae0980e/execute/sync HTTP/1.1" 500 1064
</msg>
<msg timestamp="20191209 17:24:39.968" level="DEBUG">Finished Request</msg>
<kw name="Capture Page Screenshot" library="SeleniumLibrary">...</kw>
<msg timestamp="20191209 17:24:40.603" level="FAIL">
JavascriptException: Message: javascript error: Cannot read property 'value' of null (Session info: chrome=78.0.3904.108)
</msg>
<msg timestamp="20191209 17:24:40.603" level="DEBUG">
Traceback (most recent call last): File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\__init__.py", line 467, in run_keyword return DynamicCore.run_keyword(self, name, args, kwargs) File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\base\robotlibcore.py", line 102, in run_keyword return self.keywords[name](*args, **kwargs) File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\keywords\waiting.py", line 54, in wait_for_condition timeout, error File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\keywords\waiting.py", line 265, in _wait_until self._wait_until_worker(condition, timeout, error) File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\keywords\waiting.py", line 272, in _wait_until_worker if condition(): File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\keywords\waiting.py", line 52, in <lambda> lambda: self.driver.execute_script(condition) is True, File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 636, in execute_script 'args': converted_args})['value'] File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\SeleniumLibrary\keywords\browsermanagement.py", line 660, in execute result = self._base_execute(driver_command, params) File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 321, in execute self.error_handler.check_response(response) File "c:\python37\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\errorhandler.py", line 242, in check_response raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace)
</msg>
<status status="FAIL" starttime="20191209 17:24:39.957" endtime="20191209 17:24:40.603"/>
</kw>
```

## Expected behavior and actual behavior

I would expect the default behaviour would  be to silently ignore the javascript error. In my particular instance, the web browser is transitioning from one page to another and thus, depending on a slow system-under-test, the web element of interest may NOT quite be on page just yet.

I expected that specifying a `timeout` on the `Wait For Condition` KW would have alleviated the problem but the KW still fails out pretty fast and is evident that the timeout isn't being honored.

`Wait For Condition` keyword should be able to graciously handle a JavascriptException without erroring and immediately failing the test. This could simply be, ignore the specific exception type and not error out until the timeout has expired.

After some time, effort, and sleuthing I think the offending method might be in the `waiting.py` module, in the `_wait_until_worker` where a `StaleElementReferenceException` is already being handled & ignored.

## Environment

Browser: chrome=78.0.3904.108
Browser driver: Windows 10 Pro
Operating System: Windows 10 Pro
Libraries
- Robot Framework: 3.1.1
- Selenium: 3.141.0
- SeleniumLibrary: 3.3.1
- Interpreter: python 3.7.1

items.title: Fix Create WebDriver examples
items.body: The Create WebDriver keyword example is not very good, see more details in [RF issue 3349](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/issues/3349#issuecomment-544547183). Update the example and also fix the Create WebDriver acceptance tests to use the more proper way.

items.title: Raise minimum required Robot Framework to 3.1
items.body:
To get better support for Python 3, raise minimum supported Robot Framework to 3.1. This will allow support for Python type annotations and allows Robot Framework to detect the type of the argument correctly and [convert argument to correct type](https://robotframework.org/robotframework/latest/RobotFrameworkUserGuide.html#specifying-argument-types-using-function-annotations). When type is converted correctly by Robot Framework, SL can remove all code that explicitly handles the conversio, example this type of code: 
```
if is_falsy(argument):
    code here
```

Also #1021 is automatically then done.

items.title: Raise minimum required Selenium version to 3.14 to ease support for Selenium 4
items.body:
Based Selenium 4.0.0 Alpha 3, many of the Selenium 3 deprecated methods have been removed. This change in the Selenium side, causes problems for the `Open Browser` keyword and keywords fails. We could workaround the problem by creating more code to detect Selenium version and create some code to call Selenium in proper way in proper version, but we already have quite lot of code for that in the [WebDriverCreator](https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/blob/v4.1.0/src/SeleniumLibrary/keywords/webdrivertools/webdrivertools.py#L123) class. That code is already quite complex and causes quite many bugs. Therefore I think it will be easier to raise the minimum required Selenium version to 3.14 (most likely to the latest in Selenium 3 series). This change has several advantages.

1) This cleans the `WebDriverCreator` class code quite nicely and makes it easier to read.
2) Support for Selenium 4 is easier after the requiring Selenium 3.14, most likely no changes are required.

items.title: Fix Press Keys to support multiple key pressing
items.body: There is an issue with [Press Keys](https://robotframework.org/SeleniumLibrary/SeleniumLibrary.html#Press%20Keys) and it does not support multiple keys with Chrome. This is because keyword internally uses [send_keys_to_element](https://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/py/webdriver/selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains.html?highlight=send_keys_to_element#selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains.ActionChains.send_keys_to_element). The Selenium `send_keys_to_element` API clicks element first and then sends keys to the driver. This causes input fields in Chrome to clear after each click. Fix `Press Keys` to support again sending multiple keys

items.title: Can driver specify a custom path?
add support to embed screenshots in reports

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
As discussed on [Slack](https://robotframework.slack.com/archives/C07PJBN64/p1570613885029500), as some tools (e.g. Xray and other test management related, CI) process the results from automated tests/checks based on a machine-friendly report produced by respective test runners, the report file itself should include also attachments that are related with steps.
Normally, during the execution of automated scripts, screenshots are taken at one or more steps.
In the test management tool (or in the CI tool or any other that processes the results), users want to easily see the results, which include information about step statuses (PASS/FAIL) and also screenshots. This helps users analyze results and promptly decide whether they should or not open defects.
For this to be possible, screenshots should be embedded directly in the report (in this case, in Robot's generated XML report).
They should be embedded in such a way that they can be parsed easily and in a systematic way.

As a reference, for what it's worth, Cucumber JSON reports [embed them in base64](https://relishapp.com/cucumber/cucumber/docs/formatters/json-output-formatter#embedding-screenshot).

As an example, robot framework's XML results are shown in [Xray Test Management](https://www.getxray.app/) with just the keyword level results [example](https://confluence.xpand-it.com/display/XRAY/Testing+using+Robot+Framework+integration+in+Python+or+Java). However, Xray could eventually process some well-defined information in the XML report besides [what it currently processes](https://confluence.xpand-it.com/display/XRAY/Taking+advantage+of+Robot+XML+reports).

items.title: Open Browser keyword and Selenium options with Windows path needs double escaping
items.body:
If there is a need to do add windows path by using `Open Browser` keywords `options` argument, then windows path needs double escaping. Example: 
```
| Open Browser | url | firefox | options=add_argument("-profile"); add_argument("C:\\\\path\\to\\\\profile")
```
This is both untested and not documented. Write few tests and improve the documentation.

items.title: Shadow DOM Support in Robot Framework Selenium Library 3 for testability of Google Polymer Web Components
items.body: Our application is built with Google Polymer 0.5 Web Components. In most of the pages, we are having Shadow DOMs. Multi-level Nested Shadow DOMs are also available in many pages. Depth of the Shadow DOM is from 5 to 8 levels. Now we are trying to set up end-to-end automation testing for this Google Polymer application. We are using the latest version of Selenium Chrome Webdriver along with Robot Framework and Selenium Library to automatically test the Google Polymer web pages. But Robot Framework Selenium Library is unable to simulate mouse click events especially on the web elements that are residing within multi-level nested Shadow DOMs. Robot Framework Selenium Library is able to simulate mouse click events on web elements that are residing in the Shadow DOM with a depth of 1 or 2 levels. But further down the level (For instance :- web element residing in 5th level Shadow DOM), Robot Framework Selenium Library is able to locate the elements but unable to trigger simulated mouse click events on the web elements available within multi-level nested Shadow DOMs. While attempting to trigger simulated mouse click events on web elements residing within multi-level nested Shadow DOMs, "Move Target Out Of Bounds" exception is thrown at run time. This exception is usually thrown when the specific element is out of browser view port. But this element (which is a Google Polymer "core-icon" component) is in the browser view port and also clearly viewable in the page. Googling confirmed that Shadow DOM support is not provided by Robot Framework Selenium Library. Workaround specified in some of the forums "document.querySelector('selector').shadowRoot" did not work as expected, as this Google Polymer panel (which contains the "core-icon" component) is dynamically injected at run time. So executing "document.querySelector('panelSelector').shadowRoot.querySelector('coreIconPanel')" in Chrome browser console is returning null. Since this became a major showstopper in setting up our end-to-end automation testing with Robot Framework Selenium Library, please provide details on when the Shadow DOM Support will be added in Robot Framework Selenium Library for the testability of Google Polymer Web Components.

items.title: Users should not be required to define a URL to Open Browser keyword.

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
Currently, the `Open Browser` keyword requires users to pass a URL to navigate to upon opening the browser.  However, in some cases that may not be desired and the user might simply want to open the browser. (as in the case of Chromium-based applications). 

Users should not need to specify this argument and the URL should be `None` by default. If `None` or not specified, navigation shouldn't occur.

I don't have a PR for this yet but can have one as soon as I can get back to my computer. Also sorry about the title "pay" - autocorrect :)

items.title: Should have an ActionChain click for Click Element keyword

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body: As it is now, the only way to use a native ActionChain-based click on an element is by using the `Click Element At Coordinates` keyword. It would be nice to not need to specify coordinates and just do a native click on the center of a given element. This has been implemented in PR#1462.

items.title: Input Password keyword should also prevent password being visible from the Selenium logging
items.body:
When Robot Framework log level is high enough the password is visible from the Selenium level logging. Something like this is usually seen: 
```
DEBUG | POST http://127.0.0.1:51593/session/0e87ad26dbe3d303d8b7937309367b4a/element/4beff912-9198-4dad-9d0d-46f844ddd3eb/value {"text": "FooBar", "id": "4beff912-9198-4dad-9d0d-46f844ddd3eb", "value": ["F", "o", "o", "B", "a", "r"]}
```
SeleniumLibrary  keyword should hide such entry being visible output files of Robot Framework. SeleniumLibrary will not prevent the value being visible in the keyword argument, because that is logged by Robot Framework core.

items.title: If output dir contains multiple { and } characters pairs, then opening browser with Firefox will fail.
items.body:
If robot is run with command: `robot -d {foo}_dir path/to/suite` then `Open Browser` keyword will fail with Firefox on: `KeyError: 'foo'`. This is because Python [format](https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/blob/895c1d69d0165b9d4e59ecf73c4902f2fda73314/src/SeleniumLibrary/keywords/webdrivertools/webdrivertools.py#L288) is used. Same problem also applies to [Capture Page Screenshot](https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/blob/895c1d69d0165b9d4e59ecf73c4902f2fda73314/src/SeleniumLibrary/keywords/screenshot.py#L133). 

Build a wrapper that handle formatting for Python 2 and Python 3. For Python 3: https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str.format_map is nice. For Python 2 build a something like: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17215400/python-format-string-unused-named-arguments

items.title: Fixes for documentation

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body: Proof read documentation.

items.title: "Table Header Should Contain" might get <th> elements from footer
items.body:
`Table Header Should Contain` keyword is looking for `<th>` elements everywhere in a table:

https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/blob/44a41f0a8ce719c928cd9d7fe7b33b3998006ee3/src/SeleniumLibrary/keywords/tableelement.py#L199-L200

Given that [`<th>` tag can be enclosed within `<tfoot>`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/tfoot), it doesn't seem right to treat it as a header.

It seems like a bug.

items.title: "Table Footer Should Contain" should take into account <th> elements
items.body:
`Table Footer Should Contain` is always looking for `<td>` tags within `<tfoot>`:

https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/blob/44a41f0a8ce719c928cd9d7fe7b33b3998006ee3/src/SeleniumLibrary/keywords/tableelement.py#L202-L203

but it's valid to have `<th>` tags there also. Example: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/tfoot

Can we have this keyword fixed to take into account `<th>` tags as well?

items.title: Event firing webdriver does not work with all Selenium action chains
items.body:
Selenium 3 series has a bug, https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/6604 , that event firing webdriver does not work with all action chains. Make a workaround that if event firing webdriver is used with `move_to` Selenium API (At least mouse related keywords use it.) then pass real element and not the event firing webdriver wrapped element.

In Selenium 3 we should pass WebElement, for Selenium 4 we should pass wrapped WebElement.

At least all methods using Selenium API `move_to_element` should be fixed.

items.title: Add better documentation support for plugins

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body: Currently the `Window...` related keywords work only with the currently active browser. It would be better to allow `Window...` related keywords switch browser also with the same go. Switch can be done by using browser id or alias with the in the `Window...` related keywords.

items.title: Change Open Browser keyword to register driver before selenium `get`is called
items.body: If Selenium event firing WebDriver is enabled, the Selenium before/after navigate_to is triggered before the driver is registered to the SeleniumLibrary. This causes problem for some developers and driver should be registered in to the SeleniumLibrary before any Selenium event firing WebDriver is triggered.

items.title: Add better support for plugin to add event firing WebDriver
items.body:
For plugins, it would be easier to do something like this:
```
class MyPlugin(LibraryComponent):

    def __init__(self, ctx):
        LibraryComponent.__init__(self, ctx)
        self.event_firing_webdriver  = WhatEverYouWant
```

items.title: Plugins should be last thing loaded in the SeleniumLibrary __init__
items.body:
In the library init, plugins are loaded after the Event Firing WebDriver. There was discussion in the slack that user wants to plugin to also add a Event Firing WebDriver class to the library. But this is not currently possible because plugins are loaded before the Event Firing WebDriver and it overwrites what plugin is doing.

To overcome this problem, add plugins as last in the SeleniumLibrary [__init__](https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/blob/master/src/SeleniumLibrary/__init__.py#L348).

items.title: Close Browser and Close all Browsers should timeout or handle alerts

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra help appreciated

items.body:
If an alert is open the Close Browser keywords will hang indefinitely. This is not really a fault of seleniumlibrary but in selenium itself.
More details here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48703734/why-does-the-python-selenium-webdriver-quit-not-quit

This can be mitigated by doing:
```
***Keywords***
Suite Teardown
    Go To   about:blank
    Run Keyword And Ignore Error  Handle Alert
    Close All Browsers
```

However, it would be good if seleniumlibrary would check for open alerts and close them before closing the browser to avoid this behaviour.

items.title: input text sometimes doesn't send all the keys (revisited)
items.body:
It seems we are seeing the symptom reported by closed issue #1285. As requested in the original issue, I've attached a log file with --loglevel trace in effect. Here are the details...

When we try to use RobotFramework+SeleniumLibrary under Chrome, we lose characters that are sent to the web page as input text. Here's a simple example robot script that produces the symptom for us:

```
*** Settings ***
Documentation     Simple example using SeleniumLibrary.
Library           SeleniumLibrary

*** Variables ***
${BROWSER}        headlesschrome

*** Test Cases ***
My Test
    Open Browser        https://www.duckduckgo.com  ${BROWSER} 
    Set Selenium Speed  1s
    Input Text          search_form_input_homepage  This is a test
    Click Button        search_button_homepage
    Sleep               5s
    Title Should Be     garbage to force failure for screenshot
    [Teardown]          Close Browser

*** Keywords ***
```

This should cause the web page to search for "This is a test". However, only "Thi" makes it across to the web page (see attached screenshot).

We are running on Ubuntu 18.04 with the following:

```
$ apt list 2> /dev/null | grep google-chrome
google-chrome-beta/stable 76.0.3809.62-1 amd64
google-chrome-stable/stable,now 75.0.3770.100-1 amd64 [installed]
google-chrome-unstable/stable 77.0.3833.0-1 amd64
$ apt list 2> /dev/null | grep selenium
libtest-www-selenium-perl/bionic,bionic 1.36-2 all
python-selenium/bionic,bionic 3.8.0+dfsg1-3 all
python3-selenium/bionic,bionic 3.8.0+dfsg1-3 all
$ pip list 2> /dev/null | grep selenium
robotframework-selenium2library (3.0.0)
robotframework-seleniumlibrary (3.3.1)
selenium (3.141.0)
```

There are some rather baffling details:
- We see the identical symptom with both chrome and headlesschrome. 
- The same robot under firefox works perfectly.
- We do not see the symptom (on any browser) if we are logged onto the system locally or if we use ssh+X11 forwarding to another Linux system.
- We do see the symptom consistently on Mac machines using ssh+X11 forwarding to XQuartz.

If the problem were with XQuartz, we would expect the same symptom regardless of browser. If the problem were with the chrome/headlesschrome drivers, we would expect the same symptom when the X server is on Linux. The fact that others have seen the same symptom (issue #1285) has us looking here first.

Any ideas?

![chrome_issue_screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34944431/61004208-ab51ef80-a322-11e9-9322-7ecb0941f591.png)
[chrome_issue.log](https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary/files/3379381/chrome_issue.log)

items.title: Keyword performance may suffer if remotedriver delays response
items.body:
# Prerequisites

- I have searched for similar issues in open tickets and cannot find a duplicate.
- The issue still exists against the latest released version of SeleniumLibrary.
- This is not a usage question or support request. For those, see more details in README.rst: https://github.com/robotframework/SeleniumLibrary#support
- You are not using the Java Selenium2Library: https://github.com/Hi-Fi/robotframework-seleniumlibrary-java
- Remember that this is a public forum, so remember to remove all sensitive
information, like username and password.

# For issues

_I am not sure if this is "strictly" library's fault, but I guess this issue could be abstracted out_

## Steps to reproduce the issue

_Create a simplified example which reproduces the problem. It is good if the example
can be run also by us, but this is not always mandatory._

In _some kind_ of infinite redirections (in my case it was bouncing between at least 2 URLs) **which are not caught by browser's "too many redirects" safety**, it is possible that Keyword execution performance drops to 0.

This was discovered independently in two distinct Keywords: a "benign" `SeleniumLibrary.Get Location` and a more serious `SeleniumLibrary.Wait Until Page Contains` issue.

I have traces of `SeleniumLibrary.Get Location`, but they are equivalent for `SeleniumLibrary.Wait Until Page Contains`

## Error messages and additional information
_If there is an error, run the test with `--loglevel trace` set from command line
and copy paste the full stack trace to the issue. Use https://gist.github.com/ or
similar service for anything that longer than few lines._

_Provide other details which might be useful for investigating the issue. Screenshots
from application or from unexpected dialogues are example useful. Sometimes showing
relevant parts of the log.html is useful too._

Execution of `SeleniumLibrary.Get Location`:
```robot
SeleniumLibrary . Get Location
19:51:07.261	DEBUG	GET http://192.168.0.2:4444/wd/hub/session/0d487d85e51eaa406195e102b054d3a7/url {"sessionId": "0d487d85e51eaa406195e102b054d3a7"}	
19:51:07.262	DEBUG	Starting new HTTP connection (1): 192.168.0.2	
19:54:03.576	DEBUG	http://192.168.0.2:4444 "GET /wd/hub/session/0d487d85e51eaa406195e102b054d3a7/url HTTP/1.1" 200 173	
19:54:03.576	DEBUG	Finished Request
```

## Expected behavior and actual behavior

I expect that there would be "some way" to protect against such huge delay.

Especially in the case of `SeleniumLibrary.Wait Until Page Contains`, if I have "some" kind of timeout, I would expect that it would be honored "on all levels".

_Actual behavior is that such "case of redirects" can halt test execution for too much_

## Environment

Browser: `Chromium 72.0.3626.121`
Browser driver: `ChromeDriver 72.0.3626.121`
Operating System: `Alpine 3.9.0`
Libraries
- Robot Framework: `Robot Framework 3.1.1`
- Selenium: `selenium==3.141.0`/`selenium-server-standalone-3.141.59`
- SeleniumLibrary: `robotframework-seleniumlibrary==3.3.1`
- Interpreter: `Python 3.6.8 on linux`

items.title: When Selenium Grid is used the Input Text and Input Password keywords should not do file upload if input string poinst to a file
items.body:
If Selenium Grid is used and Input Text and Input Password keywords input string points to a file, by an accident, then Selenium will think user wants to a upload a file. In this case, Selenium will transfer the file to the node where the browser is running and instead of sending a string, it will send a path to the file. Which is very hard to debug as #1398 proves. 

Instead we should prevent the Selenium automatic file transfer and order Selenium just send a string.

items.title: `Choose File` keyword should not fail if file does not exist.
items.body: Currently `Choose File` keyword fails if file does not exist, but it causes problems. See more details in #1398 . Instead we should change the `Choose File` so that it does not check if the file exist and blindly sends the sting to the browser.

items.title: Enhance documentation to explain why `Window...` keywords do not always see other browsers windows
items.body:
There was a long discussion in the Slack, why this fails in the last line: 
```
*** Settings ***
Library  SeleniumLibrary

Suite Teardown  Close all browsers

*** Variables ***
${BROWSER}  chrome

*** Test cases ***
Whatever
    ${one}=  open browser  about:blank  ${browser}
    ${two}=  open browser  about:blank  ${browser}
    ${three}=  open browser  about:blank  ${browser}

    @{identifiers}=  get window identifiers
    length should be  ${identifiers}  3
```
It was explained that each time browser is opened by `Open Browser` keyword it creates new WebDriver instance. Each WebDriver sees only the browser that it has opened and the child browsers. I never looked deeply how it actually works, but I believe that it's related to the process communication. It doesn't see the browsers opened by other WebDrivers.

Although we could change the SeleniumLibrary library functionality that it would list windows from all WebDrivers. And allows to change also between WebDriver`s 

But it would be also confusing for users, because it would change the active WebDriver and it could implicitly change how test works. I have never used those keywords that much, so I don't have strong opinion, which way would be better: 1) Current, listing only windows in the single WebDriver 2) Change to list all windows from all WebDrivers. Also change the active WebDriver in the SeleniumLibrary.

The consensus was that documentation must be enhanced, to explain the above functionality (currently it doesn't not explain). Also there has been discussion that should the keywords return all windows from all WebDrivers. But this issue is only for enhancing the documentation and if there new keywords needs to be created or existing one`s enhanced, that is done in a separate issue.

In the Slack, Bryan suggestion: _”current browser and its child windows”_ or something like that might be more clear.

items.title: Selenium version number can also contain letters
items.body:
If Selenium pre-release is installed, it will cause exception in the SeleniumLibrary: 
```
'/path/to/test.robot': Importing test library 'SeleniumLibrary' failed: ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '0a1'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/SeleniumLibrary/__init__.py", line 25, in <module>
    from SeleniumLibrary.base import DynamicCore, LibraryComponent
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/SeleniumLibrary/base/__init__.py", line 17, in <module>
    from .context import ContextAware
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/SeleniumLibrary/base/context.py", line 17, in <module>
    from SeleniumLibrary.utils import escape_xpath_value
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/SeleniumLibrary/utils/__init__.py", line 20, in <module>
    from .seleniumversion import SELENIUM_VERSION
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/SeleniumLibrary/utils/seleniumversion.py", line 23, in <module>
    major, minor, micro = int(major), int(minor), int(micro)
```
This is because the micro part of the version number contains a letter like `0a1` and the `int()` fails. Need to fix it.

items.title: When browser is closed and there is an error, the default run on failure functionality, Capture Page Screenshot, is run and it causes second exception
items.body:
When browser is closed and there is an error, the default run on failure functionality, Capture Page Screenshot, is run and it causes second exception. This is confusing for users, because there are two exceptions and it causes problems for detecting the real error, which happens when browser is closing.

We should alter SeleniumLibrary logic in such way that if there is error when browser(s) is closed and there is error raised by Selenium, the current browser is marked as `_no_current()` also when exception is raised. Now there is a bug in the `WebDriverCache` `close` and `close_all` methods that if exception is raised during `driver.quit()` the `current` remains active.
